column1: #Text=where f(t) is a dynamic fading term which is due to amplitude modulation of the FM carrier as it travels across the selectively faded deviation bandwidth.
#Text=This amplitude modulation has a bandwidth on the order of the FM baseband bandwidth (i.e. 53 kHz).
#Text=The slow fading component due to Raleigh fading is limited to about 13 Hz at highway speeds at a carrier frequency in the 100 MHz range.
#Text=This slow fading component is omitted from this model since it is assumed to be nearly constant over the analysis window.
#Text=In the presence of selective fading, the additional interference components become significant.
#Text=The prior art notch filtering technique assumed that the input signal itself is a good approximation of the FM signal, since the ratio of the analog FM power to the DAB power is high.
#Text=However, where the input signal is subject to fading and is not a good approximation of the FM signal, the processing steps can create an image which cannot be removed in subsequent stages.
#Text=The present invention solves this problem using a normalized signal extraction process.
#Text=We observe that a first multiplication of a signal shifts the instantaneous FM frequency to zero, while a second multiplication should perform the inverse of the first multiplication.

#Text=Ideally, we note that if the first and second signals are complex conjugates, and if the product of their amplitudes remains a fixed constant value, then the signal should be perfectly restored in phase and amplitude (minus the filtered out FM carrier).
#Text=Unfortunately, dynamic fading and selective fading result in amplitude variations with the fading rate and the baseband signal bandwidth.
#Text=The additional step to normalize the amplitude of the reference eliminates the generation of some of the undesirable interference associated with the original COLT technique.
#Text=This normalized extraction process is shown in FIG. 3.
